awd_titl_txt: NeTS:  EAGER:  Exploring Smart Media Pricing In QoE-Driven Network Economics To Revitalize Wireless Multimedia Resource Allocation
awd_abstract_narration:
The global internet traffic is aggressively increasing at an enormous rate, posing significant challenges to modern network protocol design. In addition, multimedia has become the "biggest big data" running through the last mile of wireless access networks, such as video on demand, cloud-based video games, and social media video sharing. This project explores potential solutions to support such big volumes of multimedia traffic over resource-constrained wireless access networks. In particular, this project investigates new approaches to improve quality of experience (QoE) for multimedia users by employing high level economic theories, orchestrating low level communication resources, and exploring selfish user behaviors among neighboring devices.

The goal of this project is to test the hypothesis that the wireless big data multimedia communication challenge could be partially solved by leveraging a new concept of smart media pricing to transform the wireless resource allocation from rate-distortion fashion to price-distortion fashion. This project pursues two coherent thrusts beyond traditional resource allocation: (1) creating a non-uniform quality-driven smart multimedia pricing model to assign different prices to multimedia packet groups with different quality contributions and decoding influences, and thus leveraging price as a new dimension in resource allocation; (2) designing a profit-driven cache delegation protocol to improve multimedia quality through offloading, and thus encouraging users to scavenge recently cached media contents from neighboring devices. The models, algorithms and protocols developed through this project could possibly identify new frontiers of pricing policy design in wireless multimedia resource allocation research. Research findings will be integrated to education curriculum and student advising, to broaden students' future career potentials and contribute to the U.S. workforce preparation.

por.por_cntn:
Mobile multimedia becomes the dominating traffic of the wireless access networks due to the increasing number of mobile users and popularity of ultra-high resolution video services. It is a critical challenge to provide Quality of Experience (QoE) to mobile users with limited wireless networking resources. This project explores new solutions to address the wireless multimedia service challenge from an economic perspective, leveraging smart pricing as a resource to provide multimedia QoE to mobile users. Specifically, a theoretical resource allocation model has been developed with consideration of economic pricing. By assigning different prices to different multimedia packet groups with various quality contributions and complex QoE influences, the design space of wireless resource allocation is expanded from networking domain to economics domain. In addition, cache delegation approaches have been designed to improve multimedia quality via rewarding offloading traffic from neighboring devices. Proper incentive mechanisms have been studied to encourage wireless users who cache and forward multimedia data to neighbors. By leveraging the cached multimedia contents on neighboring devices through short distance device-to-device communications, the QoE could be improved while the data traffic load could be reduced between the base station and the mobile users. Game theory solutions and machine learning algorithms have been developed to solve these problems.

The research and educational activities have been integrated through course contents and student advising, in order to prepare our future generations of computer scientists and engineers. Minority and female undergraduate students have been recruited and mentored through this project. Exposing to fundamental research activities in this project could benefit these undergraduate students' future career preparation.
